awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Video Transmission Through Underwater Wireless Links
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is the enabling capabilities in applications that call for both in-air and underwater operations. The aerial-underwater drones are the first drones that can fly in air, swim in water, and transition swiftly between air and water. This project aims to equip the drones with video transmission capabilities through underwater acoustic communication so that the drone need not be tethered to operate underwater. With the enabling capabilities, the drone is useful in critical infrastructure mapping, coastal environment monitoring, emergency response, coastal surveillance, and search and rescue operations.  The underwater video transmission technology can also be applied to other platforms to extend underwater wireless and mobile internet.  The capability, in turn, has the potential to enable Internet of Underwater Things. The commercial potential of the project addresses the pain points of the existing products:  the low data rate and large form factor.  The enhanced drone will enable the hybrid vehicle to create a new market that is unserved by either Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) or Unmanned Aerial Systems (UASs).

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will design and prototype a small form factor acoustic communication system for aerial-underwater drones enabling them to achieve high data-rate video transmission over underwater wireless links. The intellectual merits of the proposed acoustic communication system include: 1) real-time hardware implementation of a novel MIMO (multiple-input-multiple-output) transmitter on an embedded GPU (Graphic Processing Unit) such that the system can be powered by battery and be fit in a small water-proof container, 2) real-time hardware implementation of a Turbo equalization receiver on an FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) platform to combat the huge Doppler spread and long multipath echoes of acoustic channels, 3) video transmission by a high information data rate of more than 300 kbps over underwater acoustic links, and 4) integration of the small form factor acoustic transmitter with the aerial-underwater drones without interfering with the operation of the drones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Phase 1 outcome report

Overview

The project, Video Transmission Through Underwater Wireless Links, focused on developing an innovative acoustic communication system for a hybrid air-water drone, the Naviator. This system aimed to enable effective video transmission through acoustic link. The project's two primary goals included engineering a hardware prototype using multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technology and conducting market research for potential commercialization.

Intellectual Merit

The engineering achievements of this project have been substantial:

  1. Acoustic Transmitter Integration: A lightweight acoustic transmitter was integrated with the Naviator. This transmitter uses edge computing and specialized circuits to split video streams into parallel channels for simultaneous transmission via four transducers. Field experiments demonstrated successful transmission over distances of 400 m to 1 km, even at higher frequencies like 200 kHz – 400 kHz.

  2. Hardware Receiver Design: A hardware receiver prototype was developed to convert acoustic signals into digital formats, facilitating video recovery through complex MIMO Turbo receiver algorithms. Though limited in real-time processing capacity, the receiver showed promising results in mild underwater conditions.

  3. Field Testing and Environmental Analysis: Extensive testing in lake and ocean environments helped in understanding channel characteristics like Doppler spread and signal attenuation. The quality of transmitted and received video was also demonstrated, highlighting the system's resilience to environmental noise and interference.

These technological advancements contribute significantly to the field of underwater wireless communication, pushing the boundaries of what is possible in this challenging environment.

Broader Impacts

The project's broader impacts are evident in several areas:Innovation in Underwater Communication: The project represents a significant step forward in solving the complex problem of underwater video transmission, a key challenge in marine exploration and surveillance.

Educational and Academic Contributions: The project's findings have been shared through six conference papers and one journal paper. Additionally, it has supported academic growth through a student travel grant for a student to attend an international conference.

Commercial Potential: The successful completion of Phase 1 paves the way for commercial applications of this technology. The market research and customer discovery conducted during this project indicate a strong potential for this system in various sectors, including maritime surveillance, environmental monitoring, and underwater exploration.

Conclusion

The Phase 1 STTR project has successfully achieved its objectives, creating a solid foundation for further development in Phase 2. The outcomes demonstrate not only technical proficiency but also a keen understanding of the commercial and environmental implications of this technology. The project is well-positioned to advance the technology readiness level (TRL) of the underwater video transmission system in its subsequent phases, enhancing both its intellectual merit and broader impacts.


 

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2023
Modified by: Aristedes Costeas
